110AIEW00D, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 28, 1924

"THE GALLOPER"
The present week-end is featured by an event of utmost importance
in the university calendar—the presentation of "The Galloper" by the
Barnstormers Club. This evening the Barnstormers appear for the first
time since their transformation from the old Dramatic Club. The performances tonight and tomorrow night afford the only opportunity
during the year for students and their friends to see a Hopkins dramatic
production.
Those connected with the Barnstormers Club are enthusiastic over
their play and unhesitatingly declare it to be superior to all previous productions. Prejudiced though their reports may be, we have reason to

*

to stage the production. Without receiving pecuniary compensation, Mr.
Swindell has given up his time and devoted himself earnestly toward
coaching the cast to make the show worthy of Hopkins. Our dramatic
productions, since they were placed under Mr. Swindell's guidance some
three years ago, have reached a mark of perfection far above that of

MANY HOPKINS MEN ON
L'HIRONDELLE TEAM
Wistar Huey, Hopkins '23, was
elected captain of the L'Hirondelle lacrosse team for this year.
Huey was a regular on the Black
and Blue during the 1923 season
and has been instrumental in the
forming of the Ruxton team.
Other Hopkins men who will play
for L'Hirondelle are Middleton,
; Middleton, R; Landy, Zollers,
Huey, E. Webb, Passano, Singewald and Nelson. Another Hopkins graduate, Douglas Cotton,
will act as manager. The first
game of the season will be Saturday, when the Navy Plebes will
be encountered at Annapolis. In
the next game the L'Hirondelle
team will engage the Hopkins
stick-wielders at Homewood on
April 12.

The Oxford and Cambridge
track teams divided honors in
their fifty-sixth annual track meet
at the Queen's Club, held recently.
Each team scored five first and
was tied in one event—the high
jump. S. H. Thomson, Princeton
graduate, won two events for Oxford, the shot-put and 120-yard
hurdles, but failed to make a
showing in the pole vault, which
was won for Cambridge by his
countryman, J. S. Baird, of Yale.
B. M. Baker, Virginia, and W. P.
Stevenson, Princeton, the other
Americans, made third place in
their events, respectively the
broad jump and the 440-yard
dash.

Clarke and Booth will again be
given great opportunity to bring
more glory to Hopkins when they
meet Liddell, of Oxford, and
Fooks, of Cambridge, respectively, at the Penn Carnival.
Liddell's distance is the 100
yards and 200 yards. He holds the
British championships for these
two distances, traversing the 100
in 97-10 seconds, and the 220
yards in 21 3-5 around a curve.
Clarke will have to run a wonderful race to defeat the Englishman.
One of the greatest races of the
meet is expected when Fooks and
Verne Booth of Johns Hopkins
clash. Fooks is the present- English collegiate cross-country and
three-mile champion. He is capable of easily turning in a 9.30
two-mile.

the average amateur. Hopkins dramatics have become a real art. Such
productions as "If I Were King" and "The Purple Mask," both of
which met with one hundred per cent approval of the student body, are
examples of the coaching ability of Mr. Swindell. The entire student
body should feel indebted to Mr. Swindell for his interest in undergraduate affairs and for his loyalty to his Alma Mater.
Our interest is naturally centered at this time upon "The Galloper."
However, it is carried beyond the presentation of tonight. We look forward to the time of an all-Hopkins production, a play written and entirely produced by Hopkins men. The benefits which would be derived
by the university are obvious. Upon the financial success of this year's
production rests the possibility of the project being realized next year.
Tickets for "The Galloper" are still obtainable at the Barn. Any student
doubting the value of a Hopkins show will only have to inquire about
past performances.

"THE GALLOPER"
The present week-end is featured by an event of utmost importance
in the university calendar—the presentation of "The Galloper" by the
Barnstormers Club. This evening the Barnstormers appear for the first
time since their transformation from the old Dramatic Club. The performances tonight and tomorrow night afford the only opportunity
during the year for students and their friends to see a Hopkins dramatic
production.
Those connected with the Barnstormers Club are enthusiastic over
their play and unhesitatingly declare it to be superior to all previous productions. Prejudiced though their reports may be, we have reason to

*

to stage the production. Without receiving pecuniary compensation, Mr.
Swindell has given up his time and devoted himself earnestly toward
coaching the cast to make the show worthy of Hopkins. Our dramatic
productions, since they were placed under Mr. Swindell's guidance some
three years ago, have reached a mark of perfection far above that of

MANY HOPKINS MEN ON
L'HIRONDELLE TEAM
Wistar Huey, Hopkins '23, was
elected captain of the L'Hirondelle lacrosse team for this year.
Huey was a regular on the Black
and Blue during the 1923 season
and has been instrumental in the
forming of the Ruxton team.
Other Hopkins men who will play
for L'Hirondelle are Middleton,
; Middleton, R; Landy, Zollers,
Huey, E. Webb, Passano, Singewald and Nelson. Another Hopkins graduate, Douglas Cotton,
will act as manager. The first
game of the season will be Saturday, when the Navy Plebes will
be encountered at Annapolis. In
the next game the L'Hirondelle
team will engage the Hopkins
stick-wielders at Homewood on
April 12.

The Oxford and Cambridge
track teams divided honors in
their fifty-sixth annual track meet
at the Queen's Club, held recently.
Each team scored five first and
was tied in one event—the high
jump. S. H. Thomson, Princeton
graduate, won two events for Oxford, the shot-put and 120-yard
hurdles, but failed to make a
showing in the pole vault, which
was won for Cambridge by his
countryman, J. S. Baird, of Yale.
B. M. Baker, Virginia, and W. P.
Stevenson, Princeton, the other
Americans, made third place in
their events, respectively the
broad jump and the 440-yard
dash.

Clarke and Booth will again be
given great opportunity to bring
more glory to Hopkins when they
meet Liddell, of Oxford, and
Fooks, of Cambridge, respectively, at the Penn Carnival.
Liddell's distance is the 100
yards and 200 yards. He holds the
British championships for these
two distances, traversing the 100
in 97-10 seconds, and the 220
yards in 21 3-5 around a curve.
Clarke will have to run a wonderful race to defeat the Englishman.
One of the greatest races of the
meet is expected when Fooks and
Verne Booth of Johns Hopkins
clash. Fooks is the present- English collegiate cross-country and
three-mile champion. He is capable of easily turning in a 9.30
two-mile.

the average amateur. Hopkins dramatics have become a real art. Such
productions as "If I Were King" and "The Purple Mask," both of
which met with one hundred per cent approval of the student body, are
examples of the coaching ability of Mr. Swindell. The entire student
body should feel indebted to Mr. Swindell for his interest in undergraduate affairs and for his loyalty to his Alma Mater.
Our interest is naturally centered at this time upon "The Galloper."
However, it is carried beyond the presentation of tonight. We look forward to the time of an all-Hopkins production, a play written and entirely produced by Hopkins men. The benefits which would be derived
by the university are obvious. Upon the financial success of this year's
production rests the possibility of the project being realized next year.
Tickets for "The Galloper" are still obtainable at the Barn. Any student
doubting the value of a Hopkins show will only have to inquire about
past performances.
